reviewText:
This game could have been amazing. The graphics are nice, the levels are well designed, it feels like a retro game, all should be great! The problem is the controls, they ruined any enjoyment I got from the game at first. The maps require preciscion platforming a lot of the time, problem is jumping is extremely floaty and movement is stiff. There also seems to be an input lag, I'm using a wired Xbox 360 controller which works fine on every other game, especially on jumping. The bosses are lazy, the first three are the same boss with a different color pallet and play mostly the same but with a small twist, the fourth boss was more uniquely designed but is still just a big bird, last boss is another big bird but is the most creative and fun to fight of all. To see the true ending of the game you have to collect all of the coins which is where I'm at right now, some of them are easy to find others are not which I have no problem with. My issue here is with the map, you select a level and play it but if you run out of lives you have to return to the map and reselect a map. This can be annoying if you're stuck with having one life due to a level you're struggling with, especially when hunting for coins where you may be dying more. Lastly the hit boxes are just odd, yours is bigger than your character and you can take damage by landing on the edge, I mean top of the head but near the edge of it, of some enemies heads. Overall  it's a good game ruined by bad controls along with lazy boss design and a few bad design choices. 5/10 It's too bad there's no neutral option.

EDIT: As I continue to play this game I found two bugs that keep popping up that are worth mentioning. First of all when you gather 100 coins you gain a spare item, it's hard to explain but basically you see the icon of the item in the bottom right of the screen and when you press Y (on a controller) you use the item, if it's a power up you gain that powerup, but the problem is it works when it wants to. So many times I'd lose my powerup and try to use my spare only for it to disappear from the bottom right of my screen and me not gain the effect of the item. Next up is conveyer belts, if you happen to run into one while sprinting sometimes you use the belt as normal, other times you just move forward at walking speed, unable to turn around, across them then if you try to jump you just give a normal jump forward.

EDIT: There is one more issue I forgot to bring up, the springs. They are attrocious, the hitboxes are dead center on the spring and only a couple of pixels, which makes then a pain to use, these should be made larger in a future update, otherwise it's hard to judge exactly where I am about to be launched into the air which just makes it easy to misjudge a jump from one spring to the next, which happens many times in this game, unless you somehow have a perfect landing technique.

You can steam-roll through probably the majority of the levels, but there were some, not placed in the same pattern, that got me for a good while, either because the devs is forcing the player to take some leaps of faith at one point or another or just plain medium difficulty coupled with rage inducing moments like sliding an inch past your safety zone.

Overall, it deserves the price, as you will have couple of hours of mostly joyful playtime.
P.S: you won't fully finish the game completing world 5, you need to get all the secret coins for that .

reviewText:
It's a me. Mario.


8 Bit Boy is a 2D platforming game developed by AwesomeBlade.

Positives
- Runs at 60 FPS
- SFX = Reminds me of 2D mario games, especially the jumping sounds. Background music is mediocre though
- Great artstyle = Colourful and reminds me of the super nintendo days...
- Great Gameplay = Similar to 2D mario you need to reach the other side, whilst platforming and stomping on enemies along the way.
- Secret areas = Lots of secret areas within levels with extra coins or power ups.
- 5 stages with dozens of levels each
- Power ups = There are 3: Red, green and black which change your projectiles
- Boss fights = At the end of each stage
- Items = Like the shield which protects you from one attack
- Wide enemy variety = You will face birds, snakes, bats and different variations of them as you progress through each stage.

Cons
- No checkpoints within levels = Each death causes you to respawn at the begining of the level.
- LImited story = Basically you play as a guy who got sucked into your old game console and now has to get through the levels via platforming. Not really told during gameplay either.
- Water trap = Wished  it was red (like lava) and didn't kill you instantly when you touch it.
- Fidgety controls = Found it difficult to sprint in certain areas and kept falling off ledges.
- Limited item variety


If your looking for a good 2D mario-like platformer game, this game is for you.

reviewText:
My biggest issue with this game is how it handles death. You have to watch a 20 second cut scene every time you die at a boss fight. At the second attempt, you have no power-ups anymore, so you die in one hit. Unless you die several more times, in which case you game over and get to reload the autosave which restores those power-ups. You can't manually load the savegame; only if you game over.

Other problems:
The levels have some blind" jumps where you can't see where you have to land (and die if you guess incorrectly).
Bugs: activating a stored item sometimes fails. Also some sprites overlap incorrectly.As for the rest of the game
recommended:
music and sounds are good.
The enemies are pretty standard; reminiscent of Donkey Kong Country (except they are birds instead of crocodiles).
The levels are not especially well thought out.
You get random power-ups. A shield (an extra hit point) and several slightly different berries that let you shoot.
There is an unnecessary fake "loading" screen
hoursPlayed: which gets annoying if you die a lot.\nIf you enter a level with one life left
voteText: you have to click "yes
helpfulPercent: reload the autosave" with your mouse every time you die.\nMany hidden areas
votesHelpful: which are revealed as you enter them
votesTotal: but sometimes there is an enemy or lava one tile away
votesFunny:
which is not well thought out.
The boss fights are all similar.
Not very polished; many small things feel slightly off.
Overall it's a mediocre platformer with reasonably good pixel graphics and music. There are much better games."

reviewText:
I am a retrogamer myself. And clearly, I can tell you this game is just like a good 'old retro game (in terms of style), and it was clearly made by a retrogamer too.

First, I see some people saying this looks too much like a flash game. Well, that aint true. Flash games dont play that smooth and well. This game plays so smoothly, and the controls are hyper-responsive. This game is much more superior to a Flash game.

Graphics are good retro looking. Nothing much to say here.

The gameplay is very similar to Super Mario games. While it doesnt play as well as normal Mario, it still plays damn well. The level design isnt the best I ever saw, but the way the levels are made makes 8BitBoy a very fun platformer to enjoy.

The music is enjoyable, and I would totally love to have the soundtrack for this wonderful game.

8BitBit can be difficult in some places. So I cant say its the best platformer game for you, if you are a beginner. Like I said, this game was clearly made by a retrogamer, and old games were harder, and thus, this game is designer for better players. Its not a hard game, but not an easy one either. Just dont start with that game if you're a beginner.


8BitBoy might not look like its worth 4,49$, but dont worry, it totally is worth the price. I dont regret buying the game. Not at all. If you love retrogaming, or 2D platformers, 8BitBoy is for you. Its a true hidden gem on Steam. Absolutely recommended!!

reviewText:
Tiny Review by Alderon

Nostalgia, especially for me as an 80's/90's gamer. It pushes all my oldskool buttons, the good ones but sadly enough the bad ones too.

The good parts:
- 8-bit graphics.
- Nostalgia for older players like me.
- Simple yet deep. Easy controls but secrets everywhere.
- A save system!

The bad parts:
- Hard.
- Nothing that's not been done over a million times already.
- Remember the frustration when dying and losing your upgrades/items/stuff? Be prepared to experience it again and again.

The conclusion:
Honestly, the frustration got to me. I have gotten older and time has become a luxury. So, sorry, 8BitBoy, It was fun while it lasted. Lastly, gamepad recommended over mouse & keyboard.  I give it a 5/10.

I'm running it/steam on a MacPro, 12bg ram, 3.7 quad core, AMD graphics card. A stock entry level macpro. The game won't load up, I'm stuck on the loading screen. Seems to be an known issue. voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game could have been amazing. The graphics are nice, the levels are well designed, it feels like a retro game, all should be great! The problem is the controls, they ruined any enjoyment I got from the game at first. The maps require preciscion platforming a lot of the time, problem is jumping is extremely floaty and movement is stiff. There also seems to be an input lag, I'm using a wired Xbox 360 controller which works fine on every other game, especially on jumping. The bosses are lazy, the first three are the same boss with a different color pallet and play mostly the same but with a small twist, the fourth boss was more uniquely designed but is still just a big bird, last boss is another big bird but is the most creative and fun to fight of all. To see the true ending of the game you have to collect all of the coins which is where I'm at right now, some of them are easy to find others are not which I have no problem with. My issue here is with the map, you select a level and play it but if you run out of lives you have to return to the map and reselect a map. This can be annoying if you're stuck with having one life due to a level you're struggling with, especially when hunting for coins where you may be dying more. Lastly the hit boxes are just odd, yours is bigger than your character and you can take damage by landing on the edge, I mean top of the head but near the edge of it, of some enemies heads. Overall  it's a good game ruined by bad controls along with lazy boss design and a few bad design choices. 5/10 It's too bad there's no neutral option.

EDIT: As I continue to play this game I found two bugs that keep popping up that are worth mentioning. First of all when you gather 100 coins you gain a spare item, it's hard to explain but basically you see the icon of the item in the bottom right of the screen and when you press Y (on a controller) you use the item, if it's a power up you gain that powerup, but the problem is it works when it wants to. So many times I'd lose my powerup and try to use my spare only for it to disappear from the bottom right of my screen and me not gain the effect of the item. Next up is conveyer belts, if you happen to run into one while sprinting sometimes you use the belt as normal, other times you just move forward at walking speed, unable to turn around, across them then if you try to jump you just give a normal jump forward.

EDIT: There is one more issue I forgot to bring up, the springs. They are attrocious, the hitboxes are dead center on the spring and only a couple of pixels, which makes then a pain to use, these should be made larger in a future update, otherwise it's hard to judge exactly where I am about to be launched into the air which just makes it easy to misjudge a jump from one spring to the next, which happens many times in this game, unless you somehow have a perfect landing technique.

reviewText: Right from the start, 8BitBoy feels like a Super Mario clone. You jump over enemies to kill them, hit blocks with your hand (not your head!) to get power ups; there's even warp zones! Now, is this really a bad thing? Well, I'd say that it's more of a homage than a rip off. Sure, the similarities are there, and are pretty obvious, but I think that's the point of the game; to bring us back to that magical time in our childhood, in which simple graphics and simple gameplay were wonders.\n\nNow, even though it has similarities to Super Mario, it also feels quite unique. Rather than having a single fireball as a weapon, you can get up to two berries (what a great difference, you might be thinking, while rolling your eyes), well, in this game, you have two firing modes: forward, and upwards (diagonally). This can add a bit of an advantage for dealing with enemies. There's also many secret areas in each level, some providing alternate routes, and I'd add that it has pretty good level design, some of them can be quite challenging, but, once again, they remind me of the old days" in which games felt challenging in a special way
date: requiring me to learn the quirks of the different levels and execute them perfectly in order to beat them.\n\nWhen it comes to story
recommended: it isn't very complex. You play as this depressed guy who misses the "good old days"
hoursPlayed: and while messing around with his old 8-bit console
voteText: he gets transported into a mysterious game. I'd say that
helpfulPercent: in this game
votesHelpful: story isn't important
votesTotal: just like it wasn't important in games like Super Mario; we rescued the princess because that's what we were told to do (and
votesFunny: in fact
commentsCount: we weren't even told that we were looking for a princess until we beat the first world). It does add some background information
column17: as I said
column18: it's not really necessary for a game of this type. As for the soundtrack
column19: it's pretty simple
column20: since it keeps the 8-bit theme this game follows. Even then
column22: nothing too annoying or anything like that.\n\nWell
column24: I'd say that I recommend this game
column25: especially to those of you who enjoyed platforming games like Super Mario Bros in your childhood."

reviewText:
A fine tribute to the early 8 bit side scrolling platform days. And I mean early.
This is no beefed up rosy eyed retro remake.
The game runs fairly sedately relying more on good level design than trying to simply overwhelm the player.
The resolution is low but still feels right. The sound has that ad-lib feel of the early PC gaming days when shareware would have been the only source for this. Unless of course you owned a certain console featuring a certain italian plumber.
Those are the plus points. One of the few criticisms I can make is that the levels are a bit short.
That aside we're talking about a very keen price and a 90mb download so essentially it is still well worth the money. Recommended.

P.S It supports a 360 controller.

reviewText:
First the controller thing: I was able to play on my cheap gamepad by emulating a 360 controller using this utility: x360ce vibmod 3.1.4.1. I have no idea how it works, but all I had to do was to unzip the contents into the game's directory, and it recognized my joystick. So +1 in fact for the fact that this is similar to many older games, in that you often had to scratch your head at least once to get them to install properly. But keyboard input is also just fine.

Alright with that out of the way, I found that this game is well worth the price of four dollars, but you can see by my saying that that it's really not that exciting of a game. I would almost say it's better for children, but I believe the original classics are all around a better choice.

The market is disgustingly lacking in simple retro platformers. Almost all of them feel rushed or just simply lack that charming excellence of Mario 3 or Sonic. This one feels sort of like the graphics are over-done, and the gameplay is under-done. But, it has that sense of individuality and experimentation. The first boss level which simply entailed a big ballonish bird kind of let me know it's no Commander Keen.

reviewText: It's like Mario, but not just in the way that any 8-bit sidescrolling platformer might be compared to Mario.  8BitBoy copies the actual mechanics from Mario, and the result is just as satisfying.  Maybe some will find it derivative, but to me it all feels authentic.  The music, the character design, the ample secrets, etc. all combine to give it that 'magic' that even Nintendo hasn't always delivered.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A very competent, fun to play platformer. I'm to the third world so far, and it's difficulty level seems spot-on: not so hard as to be discouraging, not so easy as to be trivial.

The game has a very nice tendency to have lots of secrets, side areas, and bonus stuff hidden throughout each level, that adds a bit of flavor - do you go straight for the end, or get some of the bonus material?

All told, it's an extremely enjoyable and fun game that i'd recommend to anyone who likes platformers, or 8-bit nostalgia.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's good for what it is. The controls are not as tight as what I'd like for them to be, but I mean, it's fun to play and it does what it's supposed to do. If there are sequels I will expect more from them than this one. Overall, worth the money.\n\nUpdate: After having played with an xbox controller, I've found the game quite a bit more fun than before. Some of the tighter jumps can lead to combos and there is quite a bit of technical jumping. The secrets are fun to find also. On the whole, this game definitely does some things well the material it's an homage to did. This is a good brain relaxer, for sure.

reviewText:
As advertised, this platformer has the qualities of the olden times platformers.
Evil and masochistic in its ways, it has one main ability and one only concern: to make me feel rubbish at jumping and throwing fruit (the mario-like fireflower power-up that lets you shoot baddies) at some enemies that are, I assume, Angry Birds.

As you can see and as Steam can tell you, I've played it for barely 0,3 hours before giving up in anger and frustration – a game that can test my patience that way can only mean it's really good!

6,9bits/8

reviewText:
Overall - 3/5 - A GOOD BARGAIN!

8BitBoy is a classic throwback that highlights many of the features that made titles like Super Mario Bros. and Sonic the Hedgehog great. From huge levels with multiple routes to fun powerups, this title does a good job of saluting bygone greats while remaining an enjoyable game on its own. What 8BitBoy does lack is the Steam basics for a game of its price, like achievements, leaderboards, and trading cards, but if you enjoy retro 8-bit platformers, this game certainly delivers at a fair price.

Read the full review for this game and many more at Budget Gaming Review!
http://www.budgetgamingreview.com/2015/08/8bitboy.html

reviewText:
I'm just going to do a simple pros, and cons review

Cons-

There isn't a huge replay value, but just as much as the famous mario games.

The game appears very simple at the beginning, which can throw people off. (It gets better.)

Pros-

The sound effects... My god, they are great. (Grape power up, lol)

Music is something I can deal with for the whole game without having to turn it off.

The intro, is pretty great, lol.

Two play modes! Yeah, you heard me! (Hardcore, regular)

It's easy, but not too easy. (Died a few times at the same place from my lack of intelligence.)

Gave me nostalgia that I never had!

Verdict!-

Good game, as you can already see, I recommend it. It's better than any of those crappy flash mario clones by a long shot. All in all, best mario inspired game I ever played! 8/10

reviewText:
I'm not a big fan of platform games but I still spent a few hours playing this game so that I could give it, at least, a decent review.

My very first impression of the game was that it's a Super Mario Brothers clone and I was absolutely correct. In fact, even the character looks like Mario.

Besides, the character looking like Mario, the gameplay is also very similar to Super Mario Brothers. In 8BitBoy, the character breaks blocks with its head, collect coins, jump on enemies and even shoot fireballs.

The game world also feels very much like Super Mario Brothers. Even some of the sounds are very similar, if not exactly the same, as those in Super Mario Brothers.

I know, this review is for 8BitBoy but, unfortunately, the game just reminds me of Super Mario Brothers every time I look at it, every time I see it and every time I play it.

Overall, I think 8BitBoy is a good game to get specially if you are into old-school retro-style platform games. It has that 80's look and feel, it's easy to play and it has a lot of secrets for you to discover.

With that said, my rating for 8BitBoy for this review is a very positive 7 out of 10. It's not perfect and it didn't blow me away but I enjoyed playing it.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u0uTrIkXgSk

reviewText:
Commander Keen, Duke Nukem (not 3D), Mario, Sonic...

Pretty much all represented here.  I felt them all strongly, probably others as well, but these came to my mind most.

I don't feel the game really needs a review beyond the comparison.  I feel it blends elements of these four platform style games in a fun unique throwback way.  More forgiving than the 8-bit days, works with my 360 controller.

No real flaws to report, just a decent 8-bit style game.

reviewText:
I wish there was a neutral option for this kind of thing.
It's an alright game, but far from perfect. There are a lot of obvious flaws, like there first boss taking 20+ attempts so far. I'm not a platforming expert, but most of the time you don't just immediately go from really easy to impossibly hard and not allowed any powerups if you messed up in the last level.
But like I said, it's mostly a pretty solid platformer, but it feels to me a lot like something you'd get in a flash game for free. The character even looks a lot like mario.
It's alright, it's cheap, but if I were you I'd just spend a little extra and get a better platformer, like Battleblock Theater, or the origional mario for Virtual Console.

reviewText:
What is it and what are the features?
- Reminds me of Mario games from the 90's, in a good way.
- It's not very unique but it doesn't try to be.
- Collect coins, get powerups and find hidden locations.
- Hard but fun. It has a normal and a hard mode.
- A little over 50 levels to be played in 5 worlds, each with bosses.
- Sound is just like old 8-bit games.
- Runs very smooth.

Controls:
- Played it with a PS3 controller and it's much better than keyboard and mouse.
- Get the MotioninJoy drivers and the Better DS3 tool to configure the controller.

Verdict:
- Got it in a Steam sale for 0,99€, but it's worth it's original low price.
- So far I just reached world 3. Atm. I'm giving this game 8/10 for the polished nostalgia.

reviewText:
I'm recommending this game. It does what it says on the tin, which in this case is '8-Bit Platformer'. Admittedly it's an 8-Bit STYLE platformer, and the things it does well are not what makes it stand out.

This is - put simply - a polished platformer. My one and only complaint (which is rather a big one, thinking about it) - is the ending...

[SPOILER ALERT]

The game gives you the option of choosing between two difficulties at the beginning, so - I plumped for the more casual setting, as I wanted to enjoy the game in a relaxed manner. One of the extras you must complete in the 'Hard' difficulty, is to obtain a hidden coin in each level before you can progress (and it turns auto save off, so... I guess you just do it yourself..?

Anyway - come to the end of the game on casual mode, and the game informs me after the final boss that I need to go back and collect all the hidden coins before I can get the ending.

NO EXCUSES, AWFUL GAME MECHANIC RIGHT THERE. I have no desire whatsoever to repeat each level and find a coin for some arbitrary reason (the button that takes me home needs power! Feed it coins to activate it!).

[/spoiler alert]

So, with that in mind, I still recommend the game, since it was fun to play, but that ending does need tidying up, for I was not rewarded whatsoever for my effort, and have been turned off ever wishing to try. Maybe one day...

NEW PLAYERS: PICK THE HARD MODE OR FACE CRUSHING DISAPPOINTMENT.

I have produced a video series on this game, so - decide for yourself! (I even found no less than three of the hidden warp-zones, pretty pointless though, given my spoiler text!).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QCwZpiJ0wAk

reviewText:
Zero Dark Garfield

Based on a True Story

It was sunny day of shining glory when Maya was looking for Osama Bin Laden. She had been looking for ages upon years and was no closer to the capture of her quarrying.

It has been many months why have you not found Osama Bin Laden?" Asked Joseph Bradley with frustration.

"I am trying but it is hard. He hides from justice like moon hides from the sun." Maya responded with exasperation tears.

"You must keep on the hunt and be ready for the pounce
date:
America needs you." Said Joseph Bradley as he walked out.

"Where are you Osama Bin Laden?!" Cried out Maya with fist raised to sky.

Maya traveled all over world to but was no closer to the villain. She traveled to lands of desert and sand like Pakistan and Afghanistan but it was no use. Full of exhaustion and depression she went back to room to sleep.

"It is no use I am useless." Said Maya as she cried herself to slumber tears. In her dreams of sleeping agony Osama Bin Laden was running from her but she could not capture. He was giggling like school girl and ducking in rabbit holes.

"Heehee you cannot catch me." Said Osama Bin Laden as he leaped into rabbit hole. Maya jumped in after him and stumbled into twisting tunnel of spiraling chaos. When sliding finally ended she found herself in room at last cornering Osama Bin Laden.

"Hoohooheehee." Said Osama Bin Laden as he split into 20 Osama Bin Ladens!

"Nooooo." Cried out Maya in panic. Maya could not tell which Osama Bin Laden was Osama Bin Laden and her body filled with distraught. Then with suddenness Orange figure filled with manly presence appeared and breathed fire on the Osama Bin Ladens burning them all to cinder. After Osama Bin Laden burning

the figure disappeared into sunset and Maya woke up in her room. She was covered with sweating and was trembling at power she had witnessed.

"Who was that awesome power and what could this mean?" Thought Maya to herself as she shook with amazement.

As Maya sat in thoughtfulness on her bed she heard phone ring with alarming.

"Hello this is Maya who is talking?" Asked Maya with questions as she answered the phone.

"This is Leon Panetta of the CIA we need you to come to CIA Headquarters right now for update." Answered the voice with authority.

"Ok sir I am on my way." Responded Maya with obedience.

Maya flew to Washington DC USA and walked into CIA building with anxiousness. She was full of nerves since for all of her searching she was no closer to the founding. Inside she went to the elevator and hit on the button for CIA Headquarters. When she arrived at CIA Headquarters Leon Panetta and Joseph Bradley were sitting at table awaiting reports.

"Well Ms. Maya what is your status
voteText:
have you found the fiend?" Asked Leon Panetta with inquisition.

"Yes surely you must have succeeded after all this time only a total failure would have nothing." Scolded Joseph Bradley with jeering.

Maya looked down at her feet and tears fell from her eyes like drops of sadness from pools of regret.

"I AM A FAILURE." Cried out Maya as she collapsed on her knees.

"If top notch CIA agent Maya can not find Osama Bin Laden than all hope is truly lost." Said Leon Panetta with sad resignation.

reviewText:
When I only get 20 to 25 frames in this game. Makes me wonder why in the world I am. i can Run CSGO and other games like that just find. But on a platformer? One with not that great of graphics either? Obviously is something wrong with the game itself. It is fun I will have to admit. THERE IS CONTROLLER SUPPORT. If there wasnt, i honestly wouldnt have this much time on it as i do now. A platformer like mario, without controller support is not worth it at all. So thank you Dev for making that possible. Even though theres only a need for 2 buttons and a Directional Pad. Good job there Dev

I immediatly noticed the frame drop though. THis is obviously something within the program that you are using, or the build of the game, so it would be nice to actually play the game with more frames then the old nintendo itself :O

Other then that the games pretty Decent. The monsters are nice, the music is nice, and everyhing else is good too. When using a controller though, adjust it so the speed at witch you move the cursor at the main menu is faster, seems very slow.

The game is nice, worth whatever price i paid during the holiday sale. There isnt any trading cards.... FIX THAT.... I like collecting cards.... Its fun for some reason.

8/10

Dont add any stupid micro transaction

MULTIPLAYER WOULD BE THE BOMB

reviewText:
This game is alright for $3.99, but it has a lot of glaring issues with it's programming. Looks like an artist who decided they want to try and make a game without actually programming. It's typical for indie games to be made by an artist and not a programmer.

Pros:
-Nostalgia
-Responsive Controls

Cons:
-Massive Frame Drops (I can play Dragon Ball Xenoverse at 720p60FPS. Take a guess.)
-No graphics settings or frame limiters
-Story tries to be 3spooky5me creepypasta style, but ends up doing worse. (Haven't finished the game, so it might get better as it goes on.) Also the main intro plot has been done thousands of times everywhere else.
-Press down+shoot to shoot up. Down should never be jump or up. Ever.
-Physics are inconsistent (Throw the projectile upwards, goes one way. Throw it again without moving, goes on a completely different path.)
-Tries to be 8-bit, but instead produces 16-bit graphics.
-Auto-walks into the tutorial and forcing users into it. It should skip straight to a screen asking if you want to see the tutorial and if so it goes straight there and if not it skips to the game.

reviewText: 8BitBoy might be inspired by Mario and other 8Bit console titles, but actually feels a lot more like Giana Sisters. Much like Giana Sisters back in the day, it's obvious where the inspiration came from - but something feels really off and the result is a bit rubbish. While it reminds me of Mario, the physics and responsiveness of the controls aren't quite the same - making 8BitBoy feel more floaty and less responsive than it should be. 8BitBoys hitbox is kinda big and occasionally I spotted hitdetection issues which somehow seem to be a common problem with all of these modern indie-retrogames. This behaviour combined with somewhat weird physics can turn some stages and especially the bossfights into real nightmares.\n\nFor whatever reason the game plays out Super Mario Bros. 1 style the first time around (all levels have to be completed in a row) before unlocking a World Map after beating the final boss, allowing you to revisit levels and look for collectibles that will unlock the true ending. The big problem here is that you can easily screw yourself over the first time around, entering certain stages naked" - and making things a lot harder for yourself. This wouldn't be such a big deal if I was allowed to go to the world map
date: grab a power up or two or go back to an earlier stage or whatever.\n\nBe prepared for frustration as you enter death-loops until you find that room with enough coins to grant you a power-up or an item to up your chances for survival (you can always "git gud" as well ;)). Should you be stuck on a boss
recommended: have fun re-watching the boss intro each time as well as seeing the completely pointless continue-screen every couple of lives - (5-B in particular made me really mad). It really doesn't seem like much thought has been put into these aspects and they hurt the game - since you can't go anywhere else or stock up on items
hoursPlayed: frustration might happen.\n\nOn the plus-side

reviewText: The more I played this game, the more it felt like Wonderboy. But that's not exactly a compliment. What I mean is, the controls are a bit clunky for a platformer, but once you get used to them the game is not half bad, considering I got it for $0.16 in those Steam auctions. I decided to finish it and review it anyway.\n\nUnfortunately the game is backwards! The first world is not really engaging, the sound track chiptune eats away at your brain and the first boss is unnecessarily frustrating. Admittedly the game does get better as you play in to it, as I will explain in detail in a second, but I have to ask why... why not engage the players early? Oh well. Probably why it was $0.16. reviewText:
8BitBoy pays tribute to the good old era of 8bit games, especially to the Mario series, as it can easily be seen from the graphics style and later in the gameplay too.
The little history at the beginning makes us personally attached to the protagonist, the problem he is facing is very common in our generation, so I was almost envying him to be able to really escape into a game. :)

The controls are good, a little bit more difficult on a keyboard than with controller, but still okay. The thing that was bothering me was that every single time I was jumping or running, the game paused - or froze, I don't know. It was very annoying for me, because I died almost every single time.

Still recommending, because it's enjoyable, although I won't play it much because of this bug.

reviewText:
Story is a man becomes unemployed starts feeling inadequate and magically gets sucked into 8 bit gaming/console. The game is a tribute to Giana Sisters, Wonderboy in Monsterland, Psycho Fox, Rick Dangerous, Megaman, Super Mario Bros and Sonic the Hedgehog as it has an element of all those games in one way or another, still it has a significant feel to it, to be an independent title.

The sound can be grating and the graphics slightly cheesy/corny, but that is the way it is designed, again giving homage to that era of gaming. The game's strength is it's game-play. There are five worlds, 56 levels, 300 hidden locations, and 50 secret coins to find in order to get the TRUE ending.

The game literally is what saved the designer Ramus from unemployment and gave him the ability to support his family somewhat, so this game is close to his heart. You can tell this as the designer is by no means finished with it and is still continuing to update it. He has redesigned levels and is planning to add achievements and a 'secret finder' tally.

It's the most fun I have had with a game for a long while. It's challenging and enjoyable finding all those secret places. If you love games like Mario and your one of those people who has to get every coin. GET IT!

reviewText: You probably already know if you like this game.  It reminds me of crystal caves, super mario bros, or mutant mudds.  I thought it was great.  The controls feel solid and precise, and there's a run button, but I don't think you even need it to win.  There's 50 levels, plus bonus levels.  In addition to that, there's also a special token you can find in each of the levels ala collecting star coins in NSMB, and that really opens up the game for exploration giving it more play time.  It's a very fair game, that's difficult at times, but when I lost I only had myself to blame.  Anyways, it's a very good game, and I'd buy a sequel if it's as good as this one.

reviewText:
A 'terrible love letter' to retro gaming that was almost entirely plagiarized from it's idol.   For full review, please look below.

8BitBoy is a 'retro' style game created to pay homage to the old 8bit platformers of yester-century.  Sound good? There are quite a few problems I have with this game:

- By all means, pay homage to your childhood games. However, there's a line where paying homage turns into gameplay plagiarism/copying. And sadly. 8BitBoy crossed that line. The similarities to Mario are just way too much for this game to be enjoyable. Every level in this game made me feel like I've played it before - and I have.. on a better game.

- 8BitBoy promises to bring nostalgia galore from the NES era with an 8Bit classic game. Oh wait... is it 8Bit? Hell no, the graphics more resemble a 16 video game and the colour palette is definitely not something out of the NES. It would really help to make your game 8 Bit if your game is called '8BitBoy'!.

- The music is... okay. It does a decent job on providing a 16 bit (cough, cough) experience to the game. However, the sound effects are nothing short but painful. If you intent to play this, do not play with headphones unless you happen to like the smell of blood dropping out of your eyes.

- The game.. well it lacks 'fun'. The controls are awkward, mapping the run button to the fire button was NOT a good idea. The hitboxes are off and the game leaves you wanted a better made, finished game rather than an uninspired mess.    I do not enjoy playing this game - it doesn't entertain me. That is not a good recipe for a video game.


So what then? What do I play, may you ask?
http://store.steampowered.com/app/250760/
That's called Shovel Knight. It's a homage to old NES era platformers while bringing something inspiring and new to the table. I think Polygon put it best.

Shovel Knight is so much more than a love letter to the genre — it is
recommended:
the kind of game people write love letters about." - Polygon

And that's what 8BitBoy isn't. 8BitBoy is an unfinished love letter with terrible grammar - with classic lines as 'I wuv you' - and includes terrible references to other famous love letters but gets the references wrong every single time.

I think that's how I'll leave this game. It's a 'terrible love letter' to retro gaming.
Full review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6E-46yHzkxg/"

reviewText:
Summary: Poor control and same-old-same-old concept.  3/5.

This game is heavily inspired by the old Mario games, but falls short.  This game lacks the tight controls, smooth playing, and intuitive design of Mario.  If it were released in the 80's, it would have been a run of the mill NES game.  I am not saying you can't have fun with this, this is another game I wish I could give a neutral rating to.  But when I played this, I just wished I was playing SMB instead.

On the upside, the music and does represent the 8-bit era well enough.  The graphics don't always get it right.

reviewText:
What to say about 8BitBoy.....it fails on some of the basic things you need for a platformer.

Controls: These feel very loose and at times unresponsive, you are trying to make a pin point jump onto a moving platform and for the controls to fail you is just not fair, if you fail the jump through lack of skill, then that's fine, but it is not fair to poor controls.

Movement: This is just so wrong in many ways, you would only get to know what I am talking about if you played the game. But when you run, you carry far too much momentum and don't stop where you want to (which the dev could fix) but it just doesn't have the feel of the old platformer games (which the dev says inspired this game).

Jumping: The jumping in this game is just off, you think you would have to run further to get enough speed to jump further/higher right? wrong. You seem to have to jump almost as soon as you start running or else you wont make certain jumps, which is just stupid.

Overall: I would not recommend this game to anyone, old school platform lovers, people wanting to try a platformer for the first time etc etc. Just do NOT buy this, I would get a refund but I got this for free so I do not have to worry about that.

Save yourself money and disappointment, do not get this game.

reviewText:
This developer promised me a game like when I wa a child and I got just that.

First off, the character slides. Not a whole lot, just enough to ♥♥♥♥ up every jump you try to pull until you learn that momentum doesn't exist in this universe earlier. Seriously, the character movement is so poor...just like an old video game. The levels or the first seven I played are boring. Basic platforms and the same tricks over and over again. The only new thing in each level is a new type of enemy.

I thought I was getting SMB3, Castlevania, Metroid...some kind of platformer that had thought and effort put into it. This game reminds me of the games I had when I was a child, the bad ones. The ones that were too hard to be fun, to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to even mess with.

TL:DR: Wonky Control, Boring Levels, Samey gameplay from level to level with little variation thrown in. Also, why the ♥♥♥♥ does the music have to loop when I die? Just keep it playing and respawn me. It's annoying having to listen to the first 30 seconds the track over and over again which would be more bearable had the game any decent music.

reviewText: While I have a lot of appreciation for passion projects like these, I cannot recommend 8BitBoy in the slightest. While fairly competent as a platformer from a technical point of view, it quickly becomes very, very dull; after the first few levels, you have seen practically everything the game has to offer, and while new enemy types are added throughout the game, none of them really provide enough of a challenge to combat that boredom. The graphics and sounds are alright, nothing to write home about but neither are particularly offensive and they do their job well. The levels can be at times fairly elaborate and are overall quite well designed, with plenty of secrets and well-balanced difficulty, but the simplistic gameplay and complete and utter lack of innovation bury whatever potential the game might have had.

reviewText:
Boy am I glad there are world warps in the levels! I got super lucky and found my way to world 2 quickly and then found another warp to world 5. This game is built on an interesting story. Granted I didn't fight all the bosses (only 3 of 5), and I didn't play all the levels--which is a good thing in my opinion. Here's why I would recommend playing something else:

Cons:
The character movement is challenging and seems inconsistent
There are issues with collison detection, blocks don't break
You move faster walking on treadmills than trying to run--running is slower and will cause death
Many times you'll die because you must drop down and you're unable to see what's below you
It uses controller, but then has you move a mouse like finger around in the menu with the controller

All this was experience on Mac version 1.50--which is supposed to be a great stable version.

I bought it cheap, beat (first part) in a couple hours. I'm glad to be done" and moving on to something more enjoyable.

Perhaps you'll like the title
date: I'd advise picking it up on sale."

reviewText: Wanted to like this game, and gave it every chance in the book, but it constantly shot itself in the foot with terrible and repetitive level design, poor platforming mechanics, and bad game design decisions. Lets start with good like always. The game works for the most part, with only a few bugs encountered. It kind of reminds you of old NES platformers, and mario that it clearly rips off. Also there are many secrets to be found most levels and alternate routes to uncover. Then there is the bad. People are right the games hitboxes are some of the worst I've ever seen in a platformer, I've jumped on people and been killed by them so many times it's ridiculous. Someone pointed out how stupid the game design is in the fact that if you die and still have lives left, you begin with nothing you had at the start of the last life, which is super stupid and no other games does. Why would he think that was a good idea. So you just kill yourself to get back to your first life, because you want your power ups. This wastes time and makes no more than 1 life worthwhile. There are basically 2 powerups, a shield and shooting fireballs, thats it the entire game, which is super boring and uninspiring. Then there are the gameplay mechanics. The running and jumping doesn't work half the time, if you try it on a short length platforms for some reason it doesn't read it sometimes and you just jump half way. Other times it won't read you jumping even though you press it before you are off. Other times on the moving tiles you will press it perfectly and once again you won't jump...herp derp. It is almost like there is too much of a delay. On the moving platforms you will press it right away and it still won't read it. Sometimes when you land on platforms you slide, dont ask me why. The worst part is the game level design. Where as mario has interesting levels with varying things like pipes and riding ♥♥♥♥ and different levels of things to jump on, 8 bit has the same levels and they are dumb. They are all basically levels 2/3 of it with fire/water/spike that are instant kills, and you just jump onto single little platforms. This is stupid for many reasons. First off my having every level be mostly instadeath, with no checkpoints, all of your powerups you got are usually worthless because you just die and at any time if the game mechanics don't hold up, and you restart the level. Mario didn't do this, it had flat surfac levels because people don't want to have to jump over level every 2 seconds. Also by making every platform just single platforms it artifically raises difficulty and is just sloppy design. Mario and other platformers aren't all just single jumps over lava. Could have spent time and been inventive instead of making the same level. The final boss is stupid as you can't get any powerups and have to go through these 3 different attacking forms before you can hit her once, and you have to do that at least 4 or more times. If you get hit once its all over and you have to redo it all. Not worth my time. Just not that good of a platformer, obsessed with instant death and single platforms, and the wonky mechanics and hitboxes make it more frustating than fun that you have to restart levels over and over when its not your fault. 4.5/10

reviewText:
I have no idea why so many would compare 8BitBoy to Mario. If anything, this game resembles Superfrog - a billion levels with very little to set them apart from each other, and every single one is filled to the brim with secrets of varying usefulness and satisfaction upon collection. The way the stages are mostly built from a sprinkle of narrow little platforms also spells Superfrog, or a lackluster Mario hack rather than the real deal.

The features that do make me think of Mario, such as hitting blocks repeatedly for multiple coins, seem to have been borrowed without much thought. It's questionable whether these blocks were all that fun to begin with, but certainly no new ground is broken by placing them willy-nilly in empty corridors, especially in a game where separate 10-coin pickups exist.

Aside from being a mess of tiny blocks, the level design is repetitive with a noticeable lack of interesting enemy placement and unique stage features. Low-ceiling instakill pits abound. Enemies, on the other hand, usually present no challenge due to the player character's super overpowered projectile attacks that bounce everywhere and kill most baddies before they've properly entered the screen. The projectiles are lost upon death and require multiple pickups to regain, though, contributing to a shifty game balance.

The basic movement mechanics are solid enough, so if you really like bouncing around and finding a coin stash from every block of land big enough for one in an environment where nothing leaves a lasting impression, you will probably love this game. If you've actually played the nonspecific platforming greats this game tries to emulate, I'll be surprised if 8BitBoy leaves you satisfied. Unless, of course, the untouchable classic you were thinking of is Superfrog.

reviewText: Bland Mario clone. Not bad for bundle fodder if you see it with a bunch of other games for $1, but you should never buy this at full price. The controls and physics are slippery, which makes for a lot of needless frustration, and for goodness sake it's 2014 - stop with limited lives and unlimited continues. Unless the consequence of death is permadeath, don't use limited lives, it's a small but frustratingly bad design decision that way too many developers still make.\n\nThe more I play this, the worse it seems. The controls are just so slippery, basic navigation becomes a chore. A chore resulting in frequent unfair deaths. I'm not even sure this is decent for a bundle game anymore, it's just kinda bad. Has a pretty nice soundtrack and adequate pixel art, but in absence of the gameplay actually functioning properly, it's hard to count that for a lot.

reviewText:
This game is slow. The load times are slow. The segments at the start of each level telling you the level names are slow. Your cursor moves slow. Your character moves slow. Enemies move slow. It's all just so slow.
It is obvious that this game has taken a lot from Super Mario Bros. but somehow manages to be slower and clunkier than its retro inspiration.
It's not just that that makes this game not worth the very-few pixels its displayed in. The enemies and obstacles feel arbitrary and the gun-energy-ball-plasma-shooty thing doesn't seem to add anything to gameplay.
Death never feels like an issue with my skill level more than it feels like stupid errors/overshooting simple jumps/momentum carrying you a little further than anticipated.
Seriously, this game is not worth it and I can't believe there are so many reccomendations.

reviewText:
The controls make you think of old NES games where you had to build momentum to move and it felt like your character was ice skating.  That will make or break your enjoyment of this game, because it feels like the difficulty is based around mastering those kind of controls (which I personally never liked in the first place).  In a game like Super Meat Boy or Mega Man, you never feel like you died because of the controls, but I couldn't get over the sense of frustration in 8BitBoy.

The music is fine but nothing memorable, and the level designs are pretty blatant knockoffs of Super Mario World and the Super Mario Land games for Gameboy.  Collecting coins?  A plant that lets you shoot projectices?  Springs?  I wonder where you got those original ideas!?

They went for a retro feel with the intro cutscene, but they just look like flat line drawings in done in MS Paint.  Also, no one wants to read a wall of text before they play a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed platformer.  If you can't tell the story of a platformer through the gameplay, then the game doesn't need one.

The whole thing just feels like a really generic experience.  It's certainly not a *bad* game, but all it made me want to do was play Super Mario World instead.

reviewText:
I appreciate the attempt to make a good homage to the 8-bit era, but there are so many flaws in this game that thank Nyx I have beaten the campaign.

First of all, why is it so laggy when it's raining? seriously, I have a GTX 850M and I've been playing Crysis in 60fps/1080p, so why do I have to play a platformer game in 30 or 40? The only moment this runs well it's when it's indoors. And I've played it on version 1.5.3, I can't even imagine previous versions.

Second, the design level is so slow, in comparison to a TON of other platformers. I mean, I have to stop a lot of times to get past through obstacles, which shouldn't be bad, but I recognize the effort you put into designing alternatives routes in each level. This means that you wanted to remember the good old Sonic games. But these obstacles kill the pace, maybe too much to be enjoyable. It doesn't happen very often but when it does you notice.

Third, the controls. I landed on a spring of sort, and because i was in the edge of it, I didn't jump and fell off a cliff. I can't count how many times this happened. And in the late stages of the game the springs multiply in appearence, so I have to be accurate many more times than needed. This also doesn't help.

And you could use a little more variety on the enemies, since you just put a couple of snakes, some blobs that jump between cliffs, the typical flames that jump over lava, and birds, lots, lots of birds.

The best thing was when I died on a level, you restart the level expecting to have 3 lives... but you don't. You just have the lives that you had when you entered the level. WHAT THE F***? and the scoring system kept the score when you died, so the high score is the longest sitting you had during the game. I think that's not how the platforming mechanics should work.




Even though, I see all the references from the 8-bit era, from sonic to super mario bros (instead of turtles, birds, I see what you did there), and the music is fine. not the best in the world, but it's enjoyable and it helps to continue. And there are a LOT of secrets, so if you're a completionist you're going to use your brain to find them all.


But I don't recommend it. Better luck next time.

reviewText:
Mario-like platformer with decent soundtrack, creep variety and level design.The boss ispretty much the same one, just clothed differently and doing a thing more as you advance in the worlds.

You can steam-roll through probably the majority of the levels, but there were some, not placed in the same pattern, that got me for a good while, either because the devs is forcing the player to take some leaps of faith at one point or another or just plain medium difficulty coupled with rage inducing moments like sliding an inch past your safety zone.

Overall, it deserves the price, as you will have couple of hours of mostly joyful playtime.
P.S: you won't fully finish the game completing world 5, you need to get all the secret coins for that .

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine
PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game
The game is... meh. It's not terrible, nor is it unplayable.

8BitBoy is a fun and addictive game, and it holds all of the fun challenges from the era of 8-bit gaming. It's an old school Mario-style game that brings back memories of the times of Nintendo and its classic games. 8BitBiy is a decent copy of the Mario games, but all it really makes me want to do is play the original Super Mario game on my Wii Virtual Console because it all that 8BitBoy makes me feel like I am playing a flash game with very loose of controls and repetitive music!

Now to the recommendation, for its full price, I would not recommend it, BUT if it is either in a sale, price drop, giveaway, gift or even given to you as a free game then I would recommend it.

RECOMMENDED :)  Provided it is in a sale, price drop, giveaway, gift or even given to you as a free game, otherwise...

NOT RECOMMENDED :(  For its full price

reviewText: A Mario clone that while not a bad game in its own right, is dying for better art and some original mechanics. Not a waste of money at its price, but its imitation of classic Mario moves dangerously closer to imitation than nostalgic tribute. This means the game's inability to really expand on Mario too much brings forth comparisons to Mario that the game just can't meet. The level designs lack Mario's genius, the physics feel off, the platforming doesn't feel as responsive, and the art seems uninspired in comparison. The sad truth is that rather than a tribute, it feels like a cheap knock-off, and that's a shame. It really could've pushed off and been more of its own thing.\n\nDisclaimer: I recieved the game for free through a key giveaway through a website
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Actually a pretty decent and approachable difficult game. I've played this one a bit on a controller and it was like 100% better than playing it on a keyboard.

There are different stages, enemies do seem repetitive after a while (different birds, snakes and similar stuff), bossess are the same model of a big bird just with a different color and pattern of movement.

Still, the old school feeling is here and this is what makes this game enjoyable.

One note - I really recommend playing this game using a controller. It is really not fun when playing on a keyboard, because the controlls on a keyboard are somewhat laggy.

reviewText: Perhaps it's just that I was never a console gamer. I love the retro feel, but I grew up with old PC games, not console games. The dealbreaker here is the ridiculous time limit which can't even be turned off. Why put all kinds of secret stuff all over the level which seems to reward exploration, then force players to break their fingers trying to get through as fast as possible? Like I said, I'm not a console gamer. Maybe this kind of thing is de rigeur in console games but for me, it ruins what could have been a very fun game.
